msg.data:
Iterations and Matrix Multiplication

Welcome to the notebook with the assignment for the second session. You’re well on your way to obtain the Wizeline Certification for Big Data Engineering with Spark!

If you have any feedback about our courses, email us at academy@wizeline.com or use the Academy Slack channel.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Matrix Multiplication Assignment

For this assignment, you are implementing a matrix multiplication on a larger dataset than the one you’ve used so far.

We challenge you to work with two datasets, transform them into `CoordinateMatrix` objects, and ultimately convert each to a `BlockMatrix`.

msg.data:
Matrix Multiplication Assignment

For this assignment, you are implementing a matrix multiplication on a larger dataset than the one you’ve used so far.

We challenge you to work with two datasets, transform them into CoordinateMatrix objects, and ultimately convert each to a BlockMatrix.

paragraphs.text:
%md

**File Format**:
+ Each line in the text file is a row in the matrix.
+ They are comma-separated values.
+ The first value is the row index, which starts at zero. The remaining values are the matrix values for that row.

First, import the libraries you need to use  during the session with the following command:

msg.data:
File Format:
+ Each line in the text file is a row in the matrix.
+ They are comma-separated values.
+ The first value is the row index, which starts at zero. The remaining values are the matrix values for that row.

First, import the libraries you need to use during the session with the following command:

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import array, posexplode
from pyspark.mllib.linalg.distributed import CoordinateMatrix, BlockMatrix

%md
Next, use the function `spark.read.csv` to read the two matrices (`matrix1.txt` and `matrix2.txt`) on the bucket URI: 
`gs://de-training-input/matrices/`

Because there are two matrices, make a read call for each and store them in separate variables `m1s` and `m2s`. 

The `spark.read.csv` function already takes into account the commas, so there is no need to split the values manually while reading the files. The resulting objects are `DataFrames`.

msg.data:
Next, use the function spark.read.csv to read the two matrices (matrix1.txt and matrix2.txt) on the bucket URI:
gs://de-training-input/matrices/

Because there are two matrices, make a read call for each and store them in separate variables m1s and m2s.

The spark.read.csv function already takes into account the commas, so there is no need to split the values manually while reading the files. The resulting objects are DataFrames.

paragraphs.text:
// Your code goes here ...
val m1 = spark.read.format("csv")
    .option("inferSchema", "true")
    .load("gs://de-training-input/matrices/matrix1.txt")
m1.show()

%md

Now that we have loaded the data into Spark, we need to transform them into a collection of `MatrixEntry` instances.

There is no single way to accomplish this. We encourage you to do some web research and find a way that is simple and understandable.

Notice that you may need to “cross over” to the world of `RDD`s to achieve the transformation.

Be sure to store the resulting Dataset of `MatrixEntry` objects in variables `entries1` and `entries2` (we use them later on)

msg.data:
Now that we have loaded the data into Spark, we need to transform them into a collection of MatrixEntry instances.

There is no single way to accomplish this. We encourage you to do some web research and find a way that is simple and understandable.

Notice that you may need to “cross over” to the world of RDDs to achieve the transformation.

Be sure to store the resulting Dataset of MatrixEntry objects in variables entries1 and entries2 (we use them later on)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now that we have converted all of our lines into `MatrixEntry` objects (or `tuple`s in Python), we need to put them all inside a `BlockMatrix`. 

Define a function called `createBlockMatrix` that receives one of the previous objects and uses a `CoordinateMatrix` to output a `BlockMatrix`.

msg.data:
Now that we have converted all of our lines into MatrixEntry objects (or tuples in Python), we need to put them all inside a BlockMatrix.

Define a function called createBlockMatrix that receives one of the previous objects and uses a CoordinateMatrix to output a BlockMatrix.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now, we convert each dataset into a `BlockMatrix`:

msg.data: Now, we convert each dataset into a BlockMatrix:

paragraphs.text:
val matrix1 = createBlockMatrix(entries1)
val matrix2 = createBlockMatrix(entries2)

%md
Finally, to perform the optimized multiplication, use the `multiply` method of the `BlockMatrix` on the `matrix1` and `matrix2` matrices. Store the result in a variable.

msg.data: Finally, to perform the optimized multiplication, use the multiply method of the BlockMatrix on the matrix1 and matrix2 matrices. Store the result in a variable.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Once the computation is over, save the results to your output bucket. To do so, you need to transform the `result` object into a `CoordinateMatrix`, then point to its `entries` attribute, using the `saveAsTextFile` method. 

Be sure to follow the format defined in the "General Assignment Instructions" document (see your "Survival Kit"). Also, make sure to replace `<user-name>` with your personal username ID.

msg.data:
Once the computation is over, save the results to your output bucket. To do so, you need to transform the result object into a CoordinateMatrix, then point to its entries attribute, using the saveAsTextFile method.

Be sure to follow the format defined in the “General Assignment Instructions” document (see your “Survival Kit”). Also, make sure to replace <user-name> with your personal username ID.

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note:** You need to convert the `BlockMatrix` back to `CoordinateMatrix` for writing purposes.

msg.data: Note: You need to convert the BlockMatrix back to CoordinateMatrix for writing purposes.
